lines.text: Your boss is quite a card player, Mr. Kelly; how does he do it?
He cheats.
[Figuring out which con to pull on Lonnegan]

I dunno know what to do with this guy, Henry. He's an Irishman who doesn't drink, doesn't smoke, and doesn't chase dames. He's a grand knight in the Knights of Columbus, and he only goes out to play faro. Sometimes plays 15 or 20 hours at a time, just him against the house.
Roulette? Craps?
He won't touch 'em. The croupier at Gilman's says he never plays anything he can't win.
Sports?
Likes to be seen with fighters sometimes, but he doesn't go to the fights or bet on 'em.
Jesus. Does he do anything where he's not alone?
Just poker. And he cheats. Pretty good at it, too.
Can you get a mob together?
After what happened to Luther, I don't think I can get more than two, three hundred guys.
Doyle, I KNOW I gave him four THREES. He had to make a SWITCH. We can't let him get away with that.
What was I supposed to do - call him for cheating better than me, in front of the others?
Luther! Good God, we're millionaires!
Jesus! Did you know he was that loaded?
Hell no. I just cut into him. I woulda settled for pawning one of them shoes.

[losing his temper with Henry]
The name's Lonnegan! Doyle Lonnegan! You're gonna remember that name or you're gonna get yourself a new game! You follow?
[Polk greets Snyder]
Sit down and shut up, will ya? Try not to live up to all my expectations.
How much did you lose?

[winces]
All of it.
In one damn night? What are you spraying money around like that for, you could've been nailed.
I checked the place first. There were no dicks in there.
But you're a con man! And you blew it like a pimp!
Not only are you a cheat, you're a gutless cheat as well.
I put it all on Lucky Dan; half a million dollars to win.
To win? I said *place*! "Place it on Lucky D-" That horse is gonna run second!

[There is a pause, and Lonnegan runs horrified to the betting booth]
There's been a mistake! Gimme my money back!
What's your problem?
I'm putting half a million dollars on Lucky Dan to win, third race at Riverside Park.
Can't lay that off in time. A bet like that could break us.
[Hooker stares at him incredulously]
Not only are you a cheat, you're a gutless cheat as well.
What are the odds?
Four to one.
Take all of it!
[last lines]
You not gonna stick around for your share?
Nah. I'd only blow it.
You're right, Henry. It's not enough. But
[laughs]
it's close!
Dukey, if this thing blows up, the Feds will be the least of our problems.
He's not as tough as he thinks.
Neither are we.
I don't even know you.
You know me. I'm the same as you. It's two in the morning and I don't know nobody.
Listen, Gondorff! Am I gonna learn the big con or not?
What's your hurry?
I want to play for Lonnegan.
You know anything about the guy?
Yeah! He croaked Luther! Anything else I gotta know?

[after he calms down]
All right. He runs a numbers racket on the south side. He owns a packing house. A few banks.
Yeah, and half the politicians in New York and Chicago. Not a fix in this world is gonna cool him out if he blows on you.
I'll get him anyway.
Why?
'Cause I don't know enough about killin' to kill him.
You can't do it alone, you know. It takes a mob of guys like you and enough money to make them look good.
I know plenty of guys.
It's not like playing winos in the street. You can't outrun Lonnegan.
I never played for no winos.
You gotta keep his con even after you take his money. He can't know you took him.
You're scared of him.
Right down to my socks, buster! You're talkin' about a guy who'd kill a grifter over a chunk of money that wouldn't support him for two days!
[Gondorff enters the poker game pretending to be drunk]
Sorry I'm late. I was taking a crap.
Now how do you want to work this? Flat rate or percentage?
Who's the mark?
Doyle Lonnegan.
Flat rate.

You see that fella in the red sweather over there? His name's Donnie McCoy. Works a few of the protection rackets for Cunnaro when he's waiting for something better to happen. Donnie and I have known each other since we were six. Take a good look at that face, Floyd. Because if he ever finds out I can be beat by one lousy grifter, I'll have to kill him and every other hood who wants to muscle in on my Chicago operation.
Hello Snyder. Whattya doin' up here?
I'm on vacation. You see that friend of yours lately?
No, no. He packed it in. Enrolled in detective school.
Is Lonnegan after you too?
I don't know. I ain't seen anybody.
You never do, kid.
Glad to meet you, kid. You're a real horse's ass.
Luther said I could learn something from you. I already know how to drink.

[Repeated line]
You follow?
I gave him the breakout just like you said.
And?
'S good. He threatened to kill me.
Hell, kid, they don't do that, you know you're not getting to 'em.
Tough luck, Lonnehan. But that's what you get for playing with your head up your ass!
You have to keep this con even after you take his money. He can't know you took him.
Who told you this guy was in here?
Nobody. I just know what kind of woman he likes. Going to check all the joy houses till I find him.
Oh, well maybe I could help you, if you tell me his name.
I doubt it. Which way are the rooms?
Right through there. But I wouldn't go in there if I were you.
What you are going to do, call the cops?
I don't have to. You'd be busting in on the Chief of Police just up the hall.
If I didn't know you better, I'd swear you had some class!
Mr. Shaw, we usually require a tie at this table... if you don't have one we can get you one.
That'd be real nice of you, Mr. Lonniman!
Lonnegan.
[Gondorf nods and burps in response]
Hey, where's June?
She quit. I'm filling in for a couple of days, till I can get a train outta here.
Yeah? Where ya going?
I don't know. Depends on which train I get on.
